Well, it's funny, because in one sense, they are more progressive, because Peru has recognized for many years the rights of the tribal peoples there to actually own their lands.
That is to say, they get the physical title to their lands, and no one can take that away from them.
In Brazil, by contrast, Indians cannot own any land at all.
And legally speaking, they're actually treated as children.
They are deemed not to be able to - they don't have the kind of legal status of adults.

And so because they are not allowed to own any land, and the Indian territories are merely set aside by the government, they're much more vulnerable to those - the borders of those territories being changed after lobbying.
Whereas in Peru, the Indian communities can own their land, but there are very severe problems of enforcement.

And the big problem in Peruvian Amazon right now in this area where - near where these isolated Indians are living is a massive wave of illegal logging, illegal mahogany logging that is sending hundreds of loggers into these very isolated areas, which are really the last places in the Amazon where mahogany is growing in any kind of quantity.
